name: Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin)
summary: Vitamin B12, or cobalamin, is an essential water-soluble vitamin required for red blood cell formation, neurological function, and DNA synthesis. Deficiency can lead to megaloblastic anemia and irreversible neurological damage.
description: Vitamin B12 is unique among vitamins as it contains cobalt and is found naturally only in animal-derived foods. It is essential for methylation reactions, homocysteine metabolism, and myelin synthesis. Deficiency is common in strict vegans, older adults with malabsorption, and patients with pernicious anemia. Treatment often requires high-dose oral supplementation or intramuscular injections. Active forms include methylcobalamin and adenosylcobalamin, while cyanocobalamin is a common supplemental form.

metadata.natural_source: Animal products (meat, fish, eggs, dairy), fortified cereals

primary_indications: Vitamin B12 deficiency and pernicious anemia
off_label_uses: Adjunct in cognitive decline and dementia
contraindications: Caution with Leber hereditary optic neuropathy (risk of worsening vision loss)

sections.text: Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor in DNA synthesis and fatty acid metabolism. It is essential for methionine synthase in homocysteine metabolism and methylmalonyl-CoA mutase in odd-chain fatty acid metabolism. Adequate B12 supports myelin production and neurological function.

adult.deficiency injection: 1000 mcg IM weekly × 4–8 weeks, then monthly

sections.pediatric: Varies by age (0.4–1.8 mcg/day RDA); higher doses for deficiency

sections.text: Improvement in fatigue and neurologic symptoms may occur within days to weeks; anemia correction typically within 1–2 months.

serious: Hypokalemia during initial treatment of severe anemia

other: High doses are generally safe, but caution is advised in patients with Leber optic atrophy.
Monitor potassium levels in severe megaloblastic anemia during treatment.

items.action: Consider higher doses or IM administration

sections.pregnancy: Safe at recommended doses; often included in prenatal vitamins
sections.lactation: Safe and important for infant development
sections.pediatrics: Safe at RDA levels; deficiency must be corrected promptly
sections.geriatrics: Higher risk of deficiency due to malabsorption; monitoring recommended

sections.text: Not required; supplementation may be continued long-term if deficiency persists.

items: Deficiency often presents with anemia, neuropathy, and cognitive changes.
Vegans and vegetarians should ensure adequate intake through fortified foods or supplements.
Methylcobalamin may be preferred in neurological applications, while cyanocobalamin is common for general supplementation.
